Process longitudinal data in wide format with censoring

Source: R/margot-process-data.R
margot_process_longitudinal.Rd

Internal replacement for margot_process_longitudinal_data_wider(). Processes longitudinal data in wide format across multiple waves, handling censoring indicators and optional scaling.

Usage

margot_process_longitudinal(
  df_wide,
  exposure_vars = NULL,
  outcome_vars = NULL,
  preserve_temporal_order = TRUE,
  scale_continuous = FALSE,
  not_lost_suffix = "not_lost_following_wave",
  time_point_regex = "^(t\\d+)_.*$"
)

Arguments

df_wide

Wide-format data frame containing time-prefixed columns (e.g., `t0_x`)

exposure_vars

Character vector of exposure base names (without time prefixes)

outcome_vars

Character vector of outcome base names (without time prefixes)

preserve_temporal_order

Logical; if TRUE, maintains temporal ordering (t0_var, t1_var, ..., tn_var)

scale_continuous

Logical; if TRUE, scales continuous variables. Default: FALSE

not_lost_suffix

Suffix for the not-lost indicator. Default: "not_lost_following_wave"

time_point_regex

Regex pattern to identify time-point prefixes. Default: "^(t\d+)_.*$"

Value

A data frame with processed columns and censoring indicators. Future waves are set to NA for censored subjects (no carry-forward).

Details

## Censoring Propagation

This function enforces monotonic missingness patterns: - Once a subject is lost (has no data at wave k), they remain lost - All future waves are set to NA for consistency - This prevents "resurrections" where subjects reappear after being lost

## Not-Lost Indicators

For each wave k, the indicator `tk_not_lost_following_wave` is created: - Value = 1: Subject has at least some data at wave k+1 - Value = 0: Subject has no data at wave k+1 (censored)

These indicators are essential for: - Constructing inverse probability weights - Defining the at-risk set for each wave - Implementing proper survival analysis methods

## No Carry-Forward

This function does NOT implement last observation carried forward (LOCF). Missing values due to censoring remain as NA. This is intentional because: - LOCF can introduce bias in longitudinal causal inference - Modern methods (IPCW, g-computation) handle missingness more appropriately - Carrying forward values can mask the true censoring pattern
